title: Johnny Rico (author)
text:
Johnny Rico is a U.S.-born freelance journalist and war <a href="veteran">veteran</a> currently living in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">U.K.</a>. He was born Stephen Hites but changed his name to that of the <a href="protagonist">protagonist</a> of <a href="Robert%20Heinlein">Robert Heinlein</a>'s political <a href="science%20fiction">science fiction</a> novel, <a href="Starship%20Troopers">Starship Troopers</a>. His works include two non-fiction books and numerous magazine articles. He graduated from the <a href="University%20of%20Colorado%20Denver">University of Colorado Denver</a> with a master's degree in <a href="criminal%20justice">criminal justice</a> in 2001 and worked as a <a href="probation%20officer">probation officer</a> before enlisting in the <a href="U.%20S.%20Army">U. S. Army</a> following the <a href="September%2011%20attacks">September 11th terrorist attacks</a>. Rico served in the Army for 3 years, including a year in <a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> with the <a href="25th%20Infantry%20Division%20%28United%20States%29">25th Infantry Division</a>.
Rico published his first book, "Blood Makes the Grass Grow Green: A Year in the Desert with Team America" (Ballantine/Presidio, April 2007), based on his experiences as a U.S. Army Infantryman deployed to Afghanistan from 2004-2005. Critically acclaimed, <a href="Publishers%20Weekly">Publishers Weekly</a> hailed this work as "a timeless story of confounded youth and its eternal struggle for meaning, this book may well signal the birth of a titanic new voice".
Rico's second non-fiction book "Border Crosser" was published on June 23, 2009 by <a href="Ballantine%20Books">Ballantine Books</a>.
Johnny Rico has been asked to speak about his book, "Blood Makes the Grass Grow Green: A Year in the Desert with Team America", on multiple occasions. One such occurrence was on March 4–7, 2008 when he was hosted by <a href="Avila%20University">Avila University</a>. His book has also been featured in major national publications such as the <a href="Washington%20Times">Washington Times</a>.
